prompt: Historical origins of biodiesel in France, World War II era, energy crisis revival, and modern environmental considerations.
Chemical composition, production methods, raw material diversity, and environmental motivations for biodiesel.
Global energy demand projections, fossil fuel dependence statistics, and comparative emissions data.
Positive characteristics (biodegradable, non-toxic, renewable), technical advantages (low sulfur, lubricity, flash point), current challenges, and global production trends.
Feedstock availability issues, competition for agricultural land, economic subsidies, regulatory structure, market growth trends and obstacles.

Overview of biodiesel synthesis: history of raw vegetable oil use, evolution of conversion processes, transesterification as main route, economic benefits, lipid source diversity, and fatty acid composition influence.
Chemical reaction mechanism of transesterification: triglyceride conversion steps, schematic representation, and effects of reaction conditions (catalyst, temperature, molar ratio).
Principles of alkaline catalysis and feedstock requirements (low free fatty acids and moisture).
Fundamentals of acid catalysis for high-acidity oils, main catalysts (H2SO4, HCl), pretreatment applications, experimental parameters, and disadvantages (slower reaction, corrosiveness).
Objectives of biodiesel quality tests, regulatory agencies (ASTM, EN, ANP), historical standards development, compliance statistics, and specification parameters.
Importance of kinematic viscosity in engine performance, relation to fatty acid chain length, test methods, and international specifications.
Definition and significance of flash point, relation to residual alcohol content, safety implications, handling, and test standards.
Purpose of iodine value for measuring unsaturation, relation to oxidative stability, European specifications, and experimental determination method.
Saponification value as indicator of molecular weight, regulatory status, experimental method, and chemical reaction.
Importance of acid value for free fatty acid content, implications for catalyst selection, international standards, and test method.
Density relation to fatty acid structure, engine performance implications, European specifications, and experimental determination.
Oxidative stability factors, impact on quality and storage, test equipment and methodology, and international standard requirements.
Glycerol as main byproduct, engine problems due to glycerol presence, and international standard limits.
Principles and applications of thin layer chromatography (TLC) in biodiesel analysis, separation mechanism, experimental procedure, and visual comparison.
Importance of gas chromatography in biodiesel analysis, determination of fatty acid composition, experimental parameters, and chromatogram interpretation.
Principles of flame ionization detector (FID), advantages in biodiesel analysis, specific applications with chromatograms, and limitations.
Principles of mass spectrometry detector, advantages of GC-MS in biodiesel characterization, specific applications, and comparison with FID.
Application of thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in biodiesel quality assessment, thermal stability and decomposition profiles.
Use of differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) for biodiesel analysis, measuring phase transitions and thermal properties.
Edible vegetable oils (soybean, canola, sunflower, palm, peanut) as biodiesel feedstocks: advantages and limitations including food competition, cost, and availability.
Animal fats (beef tallow, lard, chicken fat) for biodiesel: conversion performance, purification challenges, and environmental impact.
Used cooking oil (UCO) and industrial waste oils: pretreatment technologies, purification, and circular economy potential.
Insects as emerging lipid source: biotechnological potential, urban production, comparison with traditional feedstocks, economic and environmental perspectives, and sanitary/legal challenges.
Biodiesel production from insects: oil extraction methods (mechanical, solvents, supercritical CO2), effect of insect diet on oil quality, and catalytic conversion adaptations.
Black soldier fly (Hermetia illucens) larvae: lipid yield by instar, fatty acid composition, cultivation technologies, transesterification studies, local production potential, and cost challenges.
House fly (Musca domestica) larvae: lipid yield by instar, fatty acid composition, cultivation, transesterification, local production potential, and challenges.
Yellow mealworm (Tenebrio molitor) larvae: lipid yield by instar, fatty acid composition, cultivation, transesterification, local production potential, and challenges.
Scarab beetle larvae (e.g., Scarabaeus spp.): lipid yield by instar, fatty acid composition, cultivation, transesterification, local production potential, and challenges.
Potential of alternative feedstocks to diversify energy matrix, reduce dependence on food crops, and enable local supply in urban areas.
Relevance of insects as lipid biomass: high fat yield per area, growth on low-cost substrates, circular economy integrating waste treatment and energy production.
Technical and economic challenges: standardization of extraction and transesterification, high cultivation costs, regulatory barriers.
Positive environmental impacts: reduced pressure on agricultural land, mitigation of emissions from organic waste disposal.
Future perspectives and research needs: new species with higher lipid content, optimization of extraction and catalysis, life cycle assessment and economic viability.
Contribution to sustainable energy transition: alignment with bioeconomy policies, interdisciplinary research, strategic role of emerging feedstocks.
